Like the rest of the state and country during the pandemic, EPCHS has moved to online schooling. Friday’s have always been Mustang Spirit Day and the administration has encouraged students and staff to support each other by posting a photo of themselves wearing their Mustang gear from home while sheltering in place. Prizes are awarded each week.

We came across this posting from an alumni on another page. We are encouraging all past Mustangs to message us photos and a short description of your time spent at EPCHS to spread a little happiness.
Thanks Gary and GO MUSTANGS!

“I came across these photos taken in December 1972. First is of my sister, Norlene Fast (Class of '75 and myself, Class of '73) and myself. Looks like we were getting ready for Friday classes or a pep rally. The Varsity team always had to wear a tie and our sweaters on Friday. Games were played on Saturday in those days.

Second photo is of Nori and our cousin, Dawn Miears Stepek (also Class of '75). Nori and Dawn were obviously on the cheerleader squad. I think all four years for them.”

post_text: Congratulations to EPCHS senior Dylan Kulovitz for a 1st Place win at the Moraine Valley Community College Welding Competition on February 14. Dylan competed against students from Stagg, Argo and Joliet West High Schools by welding a tee joint and lap joint with 6010 and 7018 welding rods. This is not the first win for Kulovitz. Two years ago he won 2nd Place at the MVCC Competition. "Dylan is a very good welder who also has good all-around mechanical skills," said EPCHS Metals Instructor John O'Connor. "I believe his goal is to join the Iron Workers Union, which would be a good fit for him." Dylan is currently working at an automotive garage.

As we celebrate this Memorial Day weekend, remembering the sacrifices and service of our men and women in the U.S. Armed Services, Evergreen Park was able to celebrate the homecoming of Marine Corps Logan Floyd (Evergreen Park Community High School Alumni). Upon graduating, Logan enlisted in the Marine Corps, and has been stationed in Okinawa Japan for the last two years. His sister, current student Elizabeth Floyd, decided that her piece for Mr. Minarik's "Hero Art Project" would be a portrait of her brother in uniform. Elizabeth says, "Joining the military takes a lot go bravery and commitment and he worked hard for it." Recently, Elizabeth received an Honorable mention in the EPCHS art show for the piece, entitled "Two Years," and was able to share it with her brother Logan this weekend after not seeing him for two years.

Evergreen Park Community High School D231
April 6, 2019 at 12:41 AM ·

On Thursday, April 4, Evergreen Park Community High School hosted a Spring Science Workshop in conjunction with the Northern Illinois Science Educators (NISE) and the South Suburban Science Supervisors (S4). The event was free and open to science teachers from all over the Chicagoland area, who were interested in sharing ideas and honing their teaching skills. The workshop went from 5:30-9:00 pm and had 21 presentations from science teachers and keynote speakers, Dr. Mark Hammergren and Dr. Geza Gyuk, from the Adler Planetarium. Approximately 100 teachers attended the workshop, which was full of networking and sharing ideas amongst teachers from a wide variety of schools, subjects, and grade levels. Teachers attending the workshop received Professional Development hours and enjoyed hours of science activities. Raffle prizes were given out and included items such as coffee mugs, laboratory manuals, science supplies, and microscopes. It was a GREAT night for those in attendance!

The workshop went from 5:30-9:00 pm and had 21 presentations from science teachers and keynote speakers, Dr. Mark Hammergren and Dr. Geza Gyuk, from the Adler Planetarium. Approximately 100 teachers attended the workshop, which was full of networking and sharing ideas amongst teachers from a wide variety of schools, subjects, and grade levels. Teachers attending the workshop received Professional Development hours and enjoyed hours of science activities. Raffle prizes were given out and included items such as coffee mugs, laboratory manuals, science supplies, and microscopes. It was a GREAT night for those in attendance!

post_text: The Evergreen Park Community High School Photo Club members explored digital photography as well as dark room photography. The first project involved using digital tools to turn their photo into what appeared to be a hand drawn sketch. For the second Photoshop project, they digitally combined two images to create one unique composition. As an introduction to the darkroom, members created Photograms and "Sandwich" prints where they combined two negatives together. Through these projects, students began to understand the basics of Adobe Photoshop and the development process in the darkroom.

The Evergreen Park Community High School Science Club went to the Willow Springs Woods in Willow Springs to help with the restoration project that is ongoing. Students that participated were Kayla Benson, Deirdra Clarke, Pat Doyle, and Ra'ell Moore-Wilson. The participants helped by removing invasive species from the forest preserve, mostly honeysuckle. Once the honeysuckle was cut, it was burned, and then an herbicide was used in order for the plant not to regrow. Removing non-native species of plants is crucial to the survival of native plants. While cleaning, students also were able to see some remnants of an old farm house foundation that is expected to be over 100 years old.

Pictured: Ms. Kathy Augustyn, Ms. Anna Papasideris, Pat Doyle, Ra'ell Moore-Wilson, Deirdra Clarke, Kayla Benson.
